Tuesday leading up to President Obama's
live primetime speech to Congress nine
o'clock tomorrow night now Citigroup is
in discussions with US officials for the
government to take a larger stake in
that trouble bank and that aid would
come from a capital injection it would
increase the government's stake in the
bank by as much as forty percent CNBC's
Melissa Lee joins us now with the latest
and I guess Melissa the question to you
is a bank nationalization is such a
dirty word at what point does it do we

government if if forty percent stake is
is a big chunk I mean I guess it's sort
of in the eye of the beholder at this
point it could just be a matter of

government a big say over potentially
how the bank is operated how it pays its

group 2 up to forty percent could happen
later today or as early as tomorrow this
just literally came in so we could be
expecting a deal at any point now and
just to go over the details of and how
this would actually work wouldn't
necessarily involve a capital injection
per se remember that the government
after injecting capital under the old
tarp has a seven point eight percent
stake in citi group 45 billion dollars
in preferred shares and the way the
government would increase at stake is
that it would convert a sizable chunk of
those preferred shares into common
equity now the impact on taxpayers
because this is important for a lot of
folks out there is absolutely nothing
because this would not involve a capital
injection although there are questions
at this point as to whether or not this
increased government state could lead to
yet another capital injection under the
new bank bailout plan more importantly
though for shareholders what this means
is dilution of the shares which
essentially means the stock price would
go down because the government is
becoming a bigger stakeholder in all of
this and you might wonder why Citigroup
approached the government because we did
learn also that Citigroup approached us
regulators as late a Sunday night to
increase at stake well simply because
the stock price fell to 18 year lows
last week touching below two dollars a
share a dollar 63 was that 18 year low
and also this week stress tests will

and federal regulators are expected to
focus on one measure of a bank's a
capital position which is known as
tangible common equity essentially what
you need to know is that under this
measure Citigroup appears to be weak and
so that was a big concern out there but
again a deal in which the government
could increase its state to the higher

Melissa thanks so much for that report
